### Environmental Knowledge Ranking Experiment

Testing student knowledge about the environment. College students see coral reefs, tropical rainforests, and wetlands as the most sensitive ecosystems, aligning with global climate narratives. However, the long tail of unique combos suggests mixed ecological knowledge and a strong opportunity to educate and personalize ecosystem awareness, especially in a Taiwanese context.

```{python}
#| label: fig-survey-envir-know
#| fig-cap: "Students' Environmental Knowledge"
#| fig-scap: "Students' Environmental Knowledge"
ecosystem_sensitivity()
```

| Rank (most-to-least chosen) | Ecosystem that sits at that rank | ≈ Share of all answers | Take-away                                                                                                  |
| --------------------------- | -------------------------------- | ---------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| 1                           | **珊瑚礁 (Coral reefs)**            | **≈ 68 %** (599 votes) | Reefs are the textbook fragile ecosystem in students’ minds. Think bleaching clips all over IG and TikTok. |
| 2                           | **熱帶雨林 (Tropical rain-forests)** | ≈ 26 % (225)           | Deforestation stories keep rain-forests firmly in the spotlight.                                           |
| 3                           | **沙漠 (Deserts)**                 | ≈ 2.4 % (21)           | Only a small crew sees deserts as sensitive – lots of folks still picture them as “already tough”.         |
| 4                           | **濕地 (Wetlands)**                | ≈ 2.4 % (21)           | Same low share as deserts. Wetlands might be off the radar unless you’re into birdwatching or flood news.  |
| 5                           | **草原 / 草地 (Grasslands)**         | ≈ 1.1 % (10)           | Grasslands barely register, even though they store heaps of carbon. Room for awareness-boosting.           |
| 6 +                         | Other rankings or blanks         | < 1 % each             | Everything outside the top five is statistical noise in this data set.                                     |


In summary, reefs dominate students mind share, with nearly 7 in 10 students putting coral reefs in the pole position. Rain-forests still matter. One quarter see them as the next-most fragile, a solid silver medal. Everything else is background noise. Deserts, wetlands, and grasslands together grab < 6 %. That’s a massive perception gap I could tackle in outreach or app content.
